data.title: Keep and restore scroll position for readonly documents
data.body:
- Start legacy protocol debug session
- Open something via "Open loaded scripts"
- scroll down
- ctrl+tab to switch to another doc
- ctrl+tab back to the newly opened script

It's scrolled up to the top. Is it being closed/opened each time we switch away?

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T14:02:52.799Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.2|
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a c++ file
2. Type any of the missing keywords into the editor (sizeof, static_cast, dynamic_cast, reinterpret_cast)

Copied from: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-cpptools/issues/551

I see that these keywords are listed in the grammar for C/C++.  I'm not sure why the editor is not coloring them correctly.

data.title: "Open Loaded Scripts" often doesn't work on second run
Docs opened by "Open loaded scripts" are blank after debug session
data.body:
- Start legacy protocol debug session
- Open something via "Open loaded scripts"
- Stop debugging

All new tabs are still open, but their contents are blank. I think either they should stay visible, or the docs should be closed completely.

data.title: Protocol "auto" suddenly required to debug simple node script. Why?
data.body:
Suddenly with the latest vscode (version 1.10.2) I am no longer able to debug a node script that contains array destructuring, e.g. `const [a,b,c] = [1,2,3];`

I was able to finally get this working by adding a launch.json configuration file that uses `"protocol": "auto"`, but this was not necessary in the previous version of vscode.

data.title: Allow to assign multiple languages for one file extension
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Version 1.10.2 (1.10.2)

```

```

data.title: "Run To Cursor" does nothing in run mode
data.body:
Related issue : https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/issues/1297

"Run To Cursor" context menu is available when the process is running. When invoked it does nothing. 

Either it should not be displayed when the application is not in a break state or it should set a breakpoint on that line.

data.title: [Theme] allow to set editor gutter background
data.body:
- VSCode Version:  1.10.2
- OS Version: Linux Fedora 25

When working with code that is all about nesting (i.e. SCSS) one really needs to see if the closing bracket 10 lines below the one you are in is at the very beginning or it has still some nesting. Usually editors help on that by having the line numbers background color be slightly different from the code background color.

So far I haven't seen any theme that makes this difference, is that because it is not possible? I would love to have that.

- Error: "Cannot launch debug target in terminal (timeout)."

data.title: Strange search behavior in default settings.json
data.body:
Hi,

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra

I see that in default settings it is not possible to just press Cmd+F for search as in any other file (I really don't see a rational reason...why? it breaks the UX...), but at least pressing Cmd+F could put the caret inside that "special" search bar, so one can start searching right after pressing the common shortcut.

Thanks!

data.title: [Debug] VSCode is sending empty "hover" evaluate requests to debug adapters.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

VSCode seems to be sending "hover" evaluate requests for "" (empty string) to debug adapters when the cursor is hovering over non-identifier symbols (semicolons, parentheses, brackets, etc).

I can't think of a language where an empty string would evaluate to anything meaningful, so this is must be a bug.

data.title: Extension Pack dependencies are not being installed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders latest
- OS Version: Mac 10.11.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Uninstall all extensions
2. Search for [Node.js extension pack](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=waderyan.nodejs-extension-pack) in extension viewlet. 
3. Click dependencies

I expect to see a list of the dependencies as contained in the extension [manifest file](https://github.com/waderyan/nodejs-extension-pack/blob/master/package.json#L30). 

Instead I see a blank list. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/23804797/491d2228-0570-11e7-9544-e31f7a201812.png)

4. Install the extension.

I expect to see a prompt asking me to install all the dependences. 
Instead I do not see the prompt. 

I expect to see the dependencies installed. 
Instead none of the dependences are installed and I see errors in the dependencies tab. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/23804859/7dff9a70-0570-11e7-989c-b6b61b93408e.png)

Some things I have tried:
- change all the extension and publisher names to lower case
- match the engine to the [Azure extension pack](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-azure-pack/blob/master/package.json)

data.title: Split documents (e.g. diffs) with focus on left switches to the right on focus loss
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (01091bb0831f7ce07db3cdc3ad66abb4141ffd8d, 2017-03-10T07:05:03.565Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a diff split view
2. Click into the left side (focus is now on the left "editor")
3. Click on the statusbar, file tree, something that won't open another editor
4. The left lost focus (correct), but now the active editor (extensions receive an `onDidChangeActiveTextEditor` event) is the right side (but still don't have focus which is fine)

You can notice this behavior much more easily with an extension like GitLens which provides "active line" annotations (you'll see them switch from the left side to the right) and statusbar updates. In GitLens specifically this causes an issue when a statusbar item is updated because of line selections on the left, and then you attempt to click on the statusbar item (to perform an action), but it fails, because the active editor switches out from under the click.

I've also noticed, when looking into this, that the line information in the statusbar isn't updated to reflect the line/column/selection of the left side -- only the right.

data.title: Let StoppedEvent's 'description' attribute override 'reason'
data.body:
With DAP change https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-debugadapter-node/issues/105 we have introduced a new optional `description` attribute for the textual representation of the StoppedEvent's reason.

As a consequence VS Code now needs to make use of the `description` attribute when showing the reason. The new strategy is as follows:
- if `description` exists use the string in the UI without modification.
- if `description` does not exist use the old behaviour (that is embed the `reason` attribute in the "Paused on" string). 
- code that needs to interpret the reason can now safely use the `reason` attribute without being affected by translations.

data.title: Insider's Update unable to close ExtensionHost during Update on Windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
For the last 3-4 days, the Insider's update has been failing when using the "Update Now" button. The Setup is failing to close background processes and gives the following error:

![codeupdateerror](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/23797682/a3b65718-0566-11e7-8786-70096677b17a.png)

I can see that there are still multiple Processes running that aren't getting closed.

![codeupdaterunning](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/23797725/ce69d4c6-0566-11e7-9320-c964505e8349.png)

When looking at what processes are still running with Process Explorer you can see that these are Extension Host processes with child Extension Processes.

![codeupdateecthost](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/23797766/033178ee-0567-11e7-9453-184563c08b2b.png)

The 2 parent processes show the ExtensionHost commandline

```
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Insiders\Code - Insiders.exe" "c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Insiders\resources\app\out\bootstrap" --type=extensionHost
```

![codeupdateexthostparent](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6662208/23797774/0951841c-0567-11e7-8bcb-7a884724e4d2.png)

I have to manually kill these processes to get the update to continue.

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I have several windows open when updating, but unsure if this has any impact. I am running the PowerShell Extension which is 2 of the still running child processes of the 2 running Extension Hosts.
2. Click the "Update Now" button to start the Update.
3. When it starts to update it errors saying it was unable to close all of the running Code processes.

data.title: Allow user to perform terminal operations relative to project root
data.body:
- VSCode Version:


Version 1.11.0-insider
Commit 01091bb0831f7ce07db3cdc3ad66abb4141ffd8d
Date 2017-03-10T07:08:40.485Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0

- OS Version:

Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:

Currently there is no way to perform an operation relative to project root. If we navigate deep into the project, we always need to identify how many `../`'s needs to be made before we can reach the root and navigate. Instead, since vscode know the project root directory, it would be better if vscode can allow navigation/shell expansion relative to project root along the lines of `~`

For e.g,

If the project is located at `/home/user/myproject`, and the user at the following path within terminal `/home/user/myproject/root/child/grandchild/`

currently if the user need to reach home, he either need to close the terminal & reopen (in which case, he would lose the history)/naguivate using `cd ../../../`

The problem with the second approach is, its waste of time identifying how many backs you need to do with elipses.

Instead if we have something like `^`(or anyother single character) which is similar to user home `~`, that vscode expands as `<project root>`, then the developers life would be much simpler to navigate within the project

This way if the user needs to navigate to `/home/user/myproject/root/child2`, irrespective of where he is in the terminal, he can just do `cd ^/child2`
